message: Despite the post from Dec 21 2015, circle shares have died, and you're looking at an archive.
Circle shares are a former feature on google+ that allowed to share bulks of up to 500 people attached to a post. It is no more. You're looking at a graveyard. Go away!
I had originally created this page to accommodate reshares of circles where my original g+ handle

appeared in. I found that wasn't a sufficiently for this page to exist, so I decided to post some of my non-mathy stuff here. Maybe as a small thank-you present. I decided to put up images of Mandelbrot's fractal set I had found over decades, and write a line or two, because it's all about writing, isn't it?

Doing this for every such reshare was a bit too much, so there had to be another solution. I had to somehow break up the stream. The most hip thing back then were engager's circles. You'd basically track when people commented or plussed your posts, or something like that. So I did that, and reshared my own circle shares here of course. And whenever that happened I started a new round with a fresh 'thank-you mandelbrot'.

But yet again, even with the picture present post, it seemed not quite enough to simply share circles, even if gathered by myself, not here for this page, but for my original account, which had to do the initial circle share! So I had to put a bit more juice into those as well. I ended up listing what I had done over the last month or so, bound together by condensed adulations for the most eager in my audience.
And all was well, we had nice after-parties to the topics the general
found amusing. And then, one morning, circle shares were gone!
I couldn't just delete what happened then, so I keep these posts here for reference. And you? You should go away now and never look back, go and see if you'd like follow my other collections!
[add link to Refurio's collection with only his original circle shares]

— Well, not really. But i miss them, and that's why I've started to collect posts of people who have engaged with me during November and December.

It's probably a better idea to do these posts as soon as each of you turns up after a new collection started. And have the collection published before anyone is in it, to get a more realtime experience for everbody.

But this time, as soon as the idea was upon me, I started to reshare random stuff. I'm not even halfway through and the feedback is already somewhat overwhelming. Apparently, that's what happens if you dial half of your phonebook at once...
The idea is to keep this collection growing until the end of the year. If we talked, and there's no post of you yet, I should be able to make one appear until tomorrow evening.
Thanks for your patience, I'm still about to figure out a way to round the corners.﻿
I put a second group on your maths links.  I thought it was better to do it as two things.
So circles have gone.  Collections are a good idea, though.
Yes I agree, I like having two posts for two collections. Although I hope to make the group large enough that my personal opinions won't matter too much.
Thank you for your considerate posting. Another fun collection!
start? Maybe pick some giants (follower wise), and drag some of their treasure lists to the light. But there are so many beautiful little gems in the dungeons...
And then there's the idea to share some of the
I felt looking into some of the larger communities. Maybe discussing matters here could help them, too. But I have to think about this a bit more.
collections are a good idea [to replace circle shares]

Well, maybe. I haven't posted much in these two months, so there are less than 100 people in these engagement circles. I think making collections even larger may not be a good idea. However, it means I might have to create many of them. I don't know if google will let me.
The other idea would be to have
- This month has been all about
. It all started ten months ago, when
first asked me about spheroids in the comments of his post:

, I greatly appreciated the chance to have a nice party with fans of his work, that's you, and I'd like to tell that all of it has been great fun for me. I'm glad to see so many enjoyed the piece, thank you!

I've been giving quite some thought wether I should batten onto the reactions John's announcement here on g+ has attracted. The rules I normally follow (see below) would have gotten about 85 people into this collection, but I figured it would be shame to lock you other people out from the benefits, just because I'm smug 'n square.
So this circle is full of engaging lovers of mathematics, you won't regret adding us!
- Some high res views from a pole.
- A ball position exposing a mysterious "shadow" of a hyperboloid.
came up with his own renderings. There are more, look at his profile!
- Here's an approach to get at he black curves in the picture, but...
...and I have some ideas to fix it, and I'm still confident that I'll be able to describe the black lines better. Also,
has come up with an unexpected idea (see appendix 3): Some of the lines appear to follow the
isochromatic lines of a polylogarithm! So the story is not at its end!
You're in this circle because you reshared, plussed or commented on one of my posts (possibly via +Spherical Reflections), or got into a discussion with me. Thank you!

The lines are isochromatic which means lines of constant phase.  So for example, the red part means it's a real number, the white dot denotes a pole, the black dot denotes a zero, blue means negative, green means purely imaginary, and purple is negative imaginary.  The contour lines run perpendicular to the isochromatic lines, so they play a role too.
, and for the new notion i didn't know before! Cute. I'll update the post, and I hope to find time to dive a bit this weekend, maybe tomorrow. I'll keep you posted.
Still posting comments on cyclotomic numbers &c.  It's part of the back door into hyperbolic geometry.  I do most of the calculations mentally, it's pretty simple, i suppose.
But thanks for including me in your engagers circle.  (or if you are into horrid puns, outragous).  It's much appreciated.
, i noticed. There are many doors to bolic geometry, or should i say mirrors? While reading Alice in wonderland
, she and her readers are a bit older now,

I found some time to reflect about the many other things, not written about in the book, connected to hyperbolic geometry. Walking the lanes of what initially appears simple to understand again and again. There seem to be only few seasons and times of day, but countless shades in between.
Trivial? Maybe, in a way, nowadays. Boring? Nah!

Btw, I rate single click salutes as engagement, so everyone plussing this post is in for example. You are especially welcome because I really like reading your posts and comments. Very much on topic for me, keep on the good work!
My hope to post something has been futile,

. Alas, I tried to overlay Li[-3] with some projections, and i'd say it doesn't quite fit. Of course, there are many more black curves, not following isochromatic contours. But the large slightly cardioidish thing? It is more elliptic, as if the more circular polylog feature was sheared.
You could also flip it, and try to match an enlarged view of the spheroid. The thing is a fractal. I haven't looked too deep, and i don't know if it approaches a polylog's isochroma shape.

There's only a little I know about the dilogarithm, its strange finite set of closed-form points, its mystifying algebraic relations. I'd expect some number theory to be at work here, and also hard-to-approximate numbers to play a role, but my inner eyesight doesn't allow me to see a connection right now.
Again, having a better idea about how the cuves work would be nice at this point. If I only weren't so occupied. Todo: Invent a time machine that generates time in the imaginary direction.

- I'm always a tad sad when i don't manage to post more. Talking to you helps me get my thoughts organized, and, more importantly, fix silly misconceptions of which i harbour many. Not being able to do that, on the other hand, raises the pressure in my head.
Knowing these cool people improved the quality of my life, have a look, tune in, add us all, and join in chatting maths now!
Regrettably, there's been only few posts last month. The first gap cleared the carpet for this hilarious paper, clearly making a point about publishers!

I don't know what drove me to write the above, but i still do think it could be lovely if we all started spicing our words with other aspects. And when it comes to gender: Why restrict to have it only one way per word? Let's have variants for all of them! Or am i just reinventing hungarian...

+wendy krieger wrote a nice playful about cyclotomic numbers. It's actually so nice that, even though it isn't directly about field theory, it's just the cup of tea that'll make one feel at home in the weird jungle of algebraic geometry i still owe you a tour of.
Despite the title, the above post isn't hard to understand. Maybe that's no surprise, because it did

cover Calabi-Yau manifolds. The journey ended one step short in the thin and clear air you breathe when you've climbed K3 surfaces. I wonder, were some of you able to use the swing of the post to appreciate the links about Calabi-Yau manifolds with new understanding?
If you found that unsatisfying, i stand by my promises, and will write more on it in the future.
My activites, the "+1" tab on my profile

Moreover, i've seen many cool other posts by cool people, and I'm publishing the links to these here, disappointingly they appear without the titles. There's a solution to that: More reshares! What do you think?
You're in this circle because you reshared, plussed or commented on one of my posts (possibly via +Spherical Reflections), or got into a discussion with me. Thank you!
I don't understnd field theory.  The ccyclotomic numbers are a subset of complex numbers.

, you said before. What i've been reading of field theory was often given in subsets of complex numbers. The notation is unsurprisingly similar, and i really think cyclotomic numbers are a handy topic to give some general audience a better grip on fields.

- Half this circle belongs to my favorite writers' circle here on g+. Thank you for welcoming me back after i've been quiet for over three months! The other half is new people. I was excited to find out that many of you do math posts, which is incredibly cool! Happy to have you here!
A little teaser: I'd like to write about moduli spaces sometime soon
My desire has been heard, and other fun posts about primes and field extensions came up in the following week.
was quick to share a nice piece on
, which are a cool and easy example for field extensions. You did it again, were this my blog i'd've invited you to do a guest post.
On the indescribable voids between humongous numbers

The topic has been haunting me quite a while, so i was relieved to realize that disallowing to write numbers greater than 10 is key to simplify a discussion to actually expose the gaps there are between very large numbers.
If you liked the style, maybe you like these 2013 posts of mine as well. I do now have some material to make one of these for
A sophisticated method to lose everything
My first serious attempt to make sense of trading tales, the maths isn't too hard, but getting a precise idea we can analyze was. Special thanks to
for offering to share his insider's insights, i'll come back to you soon!
As promised, i gathered people who had something to say about

since he has passed away. To find them (find you?), i used g+'s search bar. If you're looking for more followers, or to enhance your stream: Just pick a topic and try for yourself, and don't forget to share what you've found afterwards!

they offer, didn't you? I just noticed there's an hour of
entertaining a crowded hall. Go and have a look!

Spaces filled with rotating gears have been a topic for me before, as was anything to do with cardioids and its siblings. So i just had to share this nice animation. Thank you Gerard! Are you planning to do more of these? Who's going to be the first to do it in hyperbolic?

's profile - he's been posting historicals and anecdotes about Grothendieck you can't read elsewhere. Unlike that, but maybe interesting to you, a "Grothendieck documentary available on DVD", Apr 23:

. Hi there, you fantastic crowd! Not only have i been feverishly busy of late, and christmas upcoming, on top of that they had strangled my uplink for a week now. So i owe you all a pack of mathy posts, comments daft and curious, and many one-click salutes and appreciations.

The people in this circle are friends, all of them curious and critical readers, and many writing original and genuinely interesting stuff. I'm sure everybody here is worthy of consideration to be a friend of yours. Have a look, add us now!
has passed away. There have been some nice obituaries, but maybe not the ones in the press. I should go an collect some, maybe post them with a circle of people who appeared to care...
can be done using a "normal" sorting algorithm. Do you know more? Or want to? Drop me a note!
' call for participation, write maths in short words! Maybe just the right occupation for the months where the letters have fallen from the words, to rest beneath sentences in proofwood forest.
, following up Diagram 20 below. If you found other popular accounts lacking, maybe here's something differently too short for you. Thanks again
for prodding, me, who wouldn't see otherwise.

I've been reading fringe gravity papers of late, so there is not much noise here.  It is none the less interesting to watch the posts even if my maths is not up to it.  Thanks again
, i'll have a look. I noticed your ideas became clickable, very nice!
It's quite a chunk of mathematics
, certainly enough for me to chew on for years. I hope i can share some miniatures about the practical details soon. Maybe that'll make it more accessible.
> I've been reading fringe gravity papers of late
This is the one i'm mauling at the moment:
For a simpler introduction, ye could go for
Most of it seems to follow the six dimensions of electromagnetism, though the authors don't realise it.

The jargon downright scares me. There's some vague echo telling me gravitation and electromagnetism aren't up to explain cosmology, but i'm sure there's enough unanswered and unasked questions about the relation between the two. Somewhere near the end the plummeting jargon was overwhelming. I'm not a physicist, Jim.
But staring at the maths in between was inspiring. A bit nebulously so, but certainly entertaining. Thanks

By the why is it i'm averse against fringe physics, while it should be fringe mathematics to make me cautious? When the text is sufficiently careful to avoid claiming too much it's good fringe, isn't it?

When i come to explain the implications of the cosmological line 'Q1', the notion i see is that electromagnetism and gravity are similar because the maths is in the space itself!  But there is Q2 and Q0 to go first.

you were there in those moments, when my mathematical heart pounded in joy, and i hope it has been as delightful for you as it has been for me. I'm lucky to have you, and you know it! Keep on being curious and demanding, interested and sharing.
New here? Come and join in, add us all and tell us what you think!

It's always a pleasure.  Visitors are  making the art difficult to write.  But thanks the same.
...and by commenting you made it to the next circle
. Happy to have you here. By the way, i should thank

for sharing your picks and finds, many of which look like fun to dive into. Too bad i don't have time to try them all. Also, nice words from a professional mathematician really are something in my position. Looking forward to your next dive!
. I, too learned quite a bit from last time, special thanks for that! I'm not quite done yet with the spheroid business, btw...

. Yes. I can't help but remember how it feels when i first find something new, in a language just about understandable, to lead me deep into where i've never been before. The excitement, the feeling of elevation. Especially in my early days. I'm deeply indebted to everyone trying to bring the art down to more general audience.
The adjective "august" (in lower-case, accented on the second syllable) means "respected, impressive or venerable", so calling us "august engagers" is very flattering.  Thanks!

The adulation is fully intentional and you deserve it! Admittedly, a bit of a literary experiment went into it, but i really do feel i should express my joy and gratitude directly. Maybe, like a speaker who, suddenly overwhelmed, continues his lecture singing, i might have appeared a bit as if chasing my hat...
Obviously, not everyone contributed the same way. But especially you,

, should take my word for it. You never stop to inspire, and your radiant style did quite a bit to get me going in the first place. So please do feel flattered! And yes, while it has been sitting in shaded memories, i wasn't aware of that meaning of "august". I wish i would have been, i wouldn't have changed a thing!
And then i think: Others here (also a you thing) might, too, like to enjoy
, as i'm doing presently. To which mine might be a natural reaction. To start talking with hands and items, and to chase imaginary hats:
Thanks - you are very eloquent in your flattery.  I'm glad you're getting really excited about math.  It's an endless journey and full of surprises.

Anybody is invited to showcase a post in the comment section below. That'll sure get you in the next engagers circle, and maybe i'll reshare or post about! And please reshare this circle!
, it looks to me as if some of the motivation stems from the lack of "natural" design tools. I'm sure we're a long way from having "natural" tools.

Ten years ago, i did some sketches for a cyberdeck, William Gibson style. I tried myself at user interfaces, protocols and system architecture, to put the user in a position to quickly assemble data acquisition, filtering and presentation agents.

Just a human-data interface. I didn't get anywhere near having a grip. Suprisingly, i came to conclude that the user interface is the hard part. What the heck is a "natural" interface to effectively write code without text?
After that i spent some time with pure-data (maxx, jmax, reactor, processing, you name it). No satisfying answer there either, but lots of fun :)
I wish for such an interface. Does not seem really hard to do one which converts from distributed GLC to ... ? ... (javascript?, other?) , it's a matter of interesting development work.
I can't resist to mention java2k here...

It sure is nice to have type theory to attack systems problems like distributed computing. Monads are very helpful, too. But also having standard formats for more mathematically structured datasets would be nice (i guess types could help here as well).

I think it should be possible to implement a small suite for realtime data-fu right now - given the will. But to really lift off we'd need a user interface that can cope with messy situations. It should feel fast.
The best i could find is something like plan9's plumber togeter with dwm (window manager), but that doesn't involve "natural" programming at all...
Sorry this link isn't very helpful, the manpages referenced from there should be slightly better. Maybe i should put my abomination (written in gawk) online instead...

thanks, will read. Monads and types, can do but don't need, thanks. No semantics contradict types, nature has no types. Monads are glorified ways to input/output things and pretending  to be a virgin afterwards :)

Nice pun. No i'm not a virgin, wrote lots of code :-p And let me tell you, some of the modern stuff really is a blessing. Structuring with monads is fun and efficient, if you can get that job... But the principles technology aren't so much of of a problem. Picking a target is. And getting the manpower, in case simple won't do, but that's not the point.

(writing on g+ from a mac os x 10.4.11 is tough, but that's what I have here now) Glad you appreciated :)    I have already prepared an answer, before reading yours: if you believe (a) the Church-Turing thesis and (b) that untyped lambda calculus without eta is Turing universal, then it follows that types and functional style are useful or beautiful things, but not really necessary. From the answer I read I see that there was no need for that argumentation.
I like the post-about-a-mathematician game and would like to join! Some mathematician with computer science or biology connections would be easier for me.
!  I'm sorry I didn't get a chance to write up a post about my mathematician.  I'll get to it eventually.  I'm happy to highlight the first Youtube video I made, about my research methods:
. Everybody touching a trigger is in. Happy to have you here!
No need to feel bad about being late. You aren't. You could still be the first to answer my mass call out. After all, this is about having fun!
I like your video! You said "first", there are going to be more? That would be teriffic! Folks, go and have a look!
, after a night's sleep and a good lunch i'm not sure wether i just took your showcase personally...

Let me explain how that might have happened. Elsethread, i said i might be interested in pushing towards a software implementation for something with your GLC. My first idea would be to implement a simulator. I asked if you got sketches (or more?) for a file format or if you are interested in particular qualities for a simulator (or something else entirely), and i'd still love to get some more feedback.
Well, dreaming up benefits of new programming environments or languages could be enhanced by comparing to some of the esoteric languages, for example here on the esolang wiki:

Call it a hunch, but i think you might find interesting perspectives there. But otherwise i've grown to be a very practical guy. Albeit enjoying occasional philosophical or fictional inspirations, as soon as i see practicality in reach, i tend to become unwilling to levitate too much...

Talking about window management and pasting strings into a do-what-i-mean tool may seem too simple. I just find it hard to convey the complexity of riding a machine - and the room there is for improvement, without appealing to existing solutions. Sigh. I don't think i conveyed much.
I hope that made my previous musings less confusing (if they were), and am looking forward to your feedback.
, for including me in this circle!
thanks for the message and for the very kind offer! Something like this would be a very useful first step. One should be able first to play with it.
Please tell me what you think.
: It has been a quiet month for me, so you lot are probably not easy to be scared away by a complicated topic. Good. I like that!
You're in this circle because you reshared, plussed or commented on one of my posts (possibly via
), or got into a discussion with me. It's been fun being with you and i'm looking forward to more of it soon! Thank you!
Anybody is invited to showcase a post in the comment section below. That'll sure get you in the next engagers circle, and maybe, i'll reshare or post about! And please reshare this circle!

, you're invited to add a link to one of your posts or state your interests, no matter if you're in this circle or not.

for everyone reading, sharing and discussing here! Since i'm all about mathematics i expect many of you people to be resilient in pursuing the delights of discovery. In other words: Mathematicians! I really liked spending time with you in '13 and am looking forward to see more of it in '14!
thanks! Looking forward for lots of discussions in 2014. Related to the lambda calculus post, a more dry one, unfortunately, is this one

and reshare the circle there. The picture below is for

Over the years i picked up some tricks to find these images. The one below is on the biggest antenna of one of the circles attached to the main cardioid body. Specifically zoom towards the next biggest circle alternating left and right...
on the final day of october 2001, and stayed for practically a year. Unending walks on alternating winter streets, never burdening the (
shrinking) wanderer with choices counting past two. Colored in Kafka's thoughts, this deeply calming place leads back in time! Make sure to also try the dew dripping, unfiltered raw.

is the place where i'm going to put circle reshares so that my readers, primarily interested in maths, won't get burdened in circle posts. An expectable fallout of me experimenting with you, the public. I'll be posting pretty pictures of fractals along so it won't get too dry.
Nevertheless, when i set up that page, something magical happened. Within a day or two, about a hundred people showed up and their curiousity. And that's what this circle share is about.
I'd also like to make the page more open for others to benefit, as long as that doesn't take too much of my time. I think there should be a way. If you're interested, just ask!
A warm welcome for everyone in this
! I can only guess how you came to find this brand-new page. For those attracted by the promise in the tagline, here's my first gift: You're
! The circle below! For free! My pleasure!
If you'd like to tell about your interests or highlight a post of yours, please do so in the comment section below. It's a showcase circle!
You might have noticed that circle posts are accompanied by a picture post. This is meant to be part of the thank-you gesture. The island is for all of you!
This circle also has everyone in it who has shared a circle with a protégé of this page. I'll be making that a habit!
Currently this page has only one protégé; Me,
, the owner. If you'd like to be on the list i might consider, if your topic is related to visual mathematics. Or just convince me.

, your share started it! This gives me the opportunity to experiment with your engagers-circle concept. Also thanks for the kind words!
, you got my first post on
Here's everyone who showed interest (posted) when Shinichi Mochizuki announced he had proof for the abc- conjecture. It's been great fun to read the impressions from back then.
I have seen especially interesting posts by
, who gave very accessible first fragmentary impressions. Just search for his name and "mochizuki" and don't forget to read the comments!
's profile, who may be the one who got deepest into explaining it. And look: Colored, hand drawn diagrams! He's been posting MinuteMochizuki on his blog until mid of june and i think he'll be back!
For more here's the polymath page which, among many other interesting links, lists quite a reaction here on google+.
also made it into this circle.

As for where matters stand, it may be that Mochizuki is currently giving private lectures to Go Yamashita, a colleague, who might be inclined to do the travelling to explain it to others. Or so... that's what this blog post by Caroline Chen suggests:
Minhyong Kim, a friend of Mochizuki at Oxford, has been posting on mathoverflow an early attempt to give some overview from a closer vantage point:
And, as i must say, i stole the following taglist from
's latest circle share. You wrote some appealing stuff, your tags must be good:
It seems i missed people. I'm not sure why that happened - i did have some technical problems but i was also a bit tired.
, for one, wrote multiple posts very much worth reading. Apologies - and to anyone who'd have liked to be on it.
Well, it's too late, i can only offer people to make notice of themselves, and invite readers to also look at the ripples.

if you haven't already noticed, g+' circles are broken. details:
Missing posts: You aren't reaching everyone you think you are
TL;DR:  You possibly don't see all the posts you think you do.  And not everybody is seeing your posts, even when they think they are.
People have noticed for many months that not all the posts they expect to see will show up in their stream.  Lately, more people seem to have noticed and are being more vocal about it.  Please see
An implication is not just that you aren't seeing all the posts you expect to see; people who circle you are not seeing all of your posts.

G+ took away the slider bar for circles some time ago, and replaced it with a pull-down menu.  It no longer pretends that you have the option to see all posts from any of your circles.  You can set it to none, less, standard, or more, and add notifications if you like.  However, one expects that if you view an individual circle, you'll be able to see all the posts.

I'm doing an experiment.  Going to random circles, I am checking the posts in the circle stream (opposed to the default all-in stream), and comparing what is listed to individual profiles.*  I will note how many people are in the circle (as some hypothesised that it was connected to the number of people in a circle), and whether the person is in more than one of my circles.
So, as of the time that I checked, and on Toronto time for May 6, 2013, this is how many of each person's/page's posts that were shown in the circle stream:
PS: Posts seen in individual circle stream
PP: Posts showing on user's profile page
n: Number of people in circle
>1: Have in more than one circle
I also had it reinforced that I need to clean up and organise my circles better.  :p

I'll continue this on random days.  But the point is that even if you don't mind missing posts (which I do, otherwise I wouldn't have circled people), people who want to read you and who think they're reading your posts may be missing several of them.

So far, I don't see a pattern to this.  I sort of expected that people who posted more would have more posts missing, compared to those who didn't post much.  I also was open to the possibility that circle size made a difference.  And please don't go off on some conspiracy by Google rant, even not all of their posts are showing.  And it doesn't seem to matter if somebody is verified, or has lots of followers.

This is not going to be controlled, as people post different amounts on different days.  Also, I may add or remove people from circles (although I'll try to hold off until I have more data).  On top of all this, it isn't really reproduceable.  I've reloaded pages, and seen a post disappear, go to the profile, and see that the post has not been removed.  The overall point is that you are not necessarily seeing everything you think you should be, and people are likely not seeing all of your posts.

If you're listed at 100% here, it may not be so for everybody.  It may not be so if I re-load the circle up at a different time.  Likewise, me not seeing any, or just some of your posts does not mean that there aren't others who see all of them.

.  If there's absolutely no way to see the posts I want to in my general stream, or even in my individual circle streams, at least please give hints on whether there is any way whatsoever to see the posts I want without going to every single individual profile every day.  Which is not feasible.  I do not care what
think is relevant, and it seems that many agree.
want to make that decision.  Many of us left Facebook for a reason.
And please let us know if there's a way to ensure that we can make particular posts be seen without notifying.

* I do account for the circle stream not being in the same order as time posted, due to plusses, comments, and edits.  I check well into previous days to make sure I'm not missing a post for that reason.  I also do not count posts on a profile page that went to communities, or check-in posts.
** I will put this in a spreadsheet, promise.  And then figure out how to imbed it.  Apparently I don't work well with the combination of a non-fixed width font, and no ability to tab.  :)
